text: the reason I came back to Olympic
weightlifting was for one reason and
that is to compete at the Olympic Games
my name is Melanie Roach I'm 33 years
old I have three kids one who has autism
I'm a business owner and the wife of the
state representative eight weeks before
the Olympic Trials in the year 2000 I
herniated a disc in my back I would say
that sitting in the stands and watching
those women fight for those four spots
up to that point was the most
devastating time in my life I took about
five years off between the 2000 Olympics
and my return to weightlifting this time
around this Olympic pursuit has been a
an extremely large group effort it
includes my husband and my kids and my

quick yep
to the bar my chiropractor so we got to

I have the greatest husband in the world
I've known it since the very first day
that we've been married I know she can
do this and she needs some help to do it
I'm willing to give that help I'm going
to do whatever it takes to to get her to
be able to attain that goal for me to
come to him on a Sunday afternoon with a
four week old daughter two other
children campaigns to run every other
year and our business to run and ask him
to let me go back to weightlifting he
didn't even hesitate
he knew that was something I had always
wanted and he has put everything into
this Olympic pursuit he wants it just as

you know our mornings our whirlwind you

and he is
I guess he's the challenge right now for

quiet for do when he tantrums it ends up

yeah me you trying to help brother feel

and transition him into something else
so he can forget about whatever he was
tensioning right now you are okay we
need to go run off with some energy I
think hey you're okay it's difficult to
let go of the expectations you have for
your child and you have to kind of come
to the realization that the things you
thought he might become or the
experiences that you think are normal
for your children sometimes don't happen
with a child with autism so for me it
was about letting go of all the things
that I thought he might do and to
finally embrace who he was and to not
think too much about the future and to
just enjoy who he is now can you do it
you do it do you do it people kind of
look at me funny when I say that
weightlifting is the easiest part of my
day but it's true on the way down to the
gym I turn on the music and I relax yeah
this is where I take a deep breath and I
think oh now I get a few minutes to
myself I think that having drew and the
challenges that come with having a son
with autism is what has made me a better
weightlifter I think that I'm a better
weightlifter because I understand that I
can't think about the future
I can't worry about what's going to
happen at the next competition what my
job is now is to go in everyday
and to work as hard as I can and to
enjoy where I am today and that is what
has made me so much better if I could
put this into perspective for people to
understand what this Olympics means to
me it's the culmination of 14 years of
dreaming and wanting and and working
hard for it but I would trade every
minute in international competition
every blessing that it's been in my life
for a cure for autism
